title: Correct Measurement-Error Bias
text: conjoint experiments, measurement error pervasive often overlooked.Respondents may: Misread attributes Misunderstand levels Click randomly Forget information across tasks result, even respondent true preferences, recorded choices often noisy reflections preferences. random error introduces severe bias toward zero ‚Äî meaning estimated effects systematically small.

what: How projoint Corrects for Measurement Error
title: Correct Measurement-Error Bias
text: Estimates intra-respondent reliability (IRR) using repeated task Adjusts marginal means (MMs) average marginal component effects (AMCEs) accordingly Provides corrected estimates closer respondents‚Äô true underlying preferences ‚úÖ additional respondent burden (just one repeated task) ‚úÖ Minimal survey design changes ‚úÖ Massive improvements accuracy

title: Correct Measurement-Error Bias
text: üß† Measurement error systematically biases results. üî• Correcting measurement error reveals true preferences, sharper trade-offs, prevents misleading inferences.

title: Correct Measurement-Error Bias
text: Clayton, Horiuchi, Kaufman, King, Komisarchik (Forthcoming).Correcting Measurement Error Bias Conjoint Survey Experiments.Forthcoming, American Journal Political Science.Pre-Print Available

title: Choice-Level Analysis
text: traditional conjoint analysis, researchers typically estimate profile-level quantities, treating profile independently. approach become standard, particularly influential work Hainmueller, Hopkins, Yamamoto (2014). method rests important assumption: profile independently generated. However, profile-level analysis can systematically miss people actually make decisions. Key Issues: Compare candidates two parties: Candidates always differ two profiles Compare policy proposals status quo: One profile always fixed, another randomly generated. Compare trade-offs: two profiles specifically designed based research question (e.g., Asian Democrats vote Asian Republican White Democrat?) Compare candidate electability: sum two percentages 100. Compare two candidates‚Äô policy differences: left-leaning candidate‚Äôs policies (attributes) always positioned left. individuals compare two profiles side--side (conjoint tasks), evaluations often psychologically influenced alternative (See Horiuchi-Johnson paper).

title: Choice-Level Analysis
text: Choice-level analysis models decision two profiles, evaluation single profile. approach better reflects: people make real-world tradeoffs (e.g., choosing candidates, products, policies) comparative contexts influence judgments (e.g., assimilation, contrast effects) Rather estimating probability selecting standalone profile, choice-level analysis estimates probability choosing one profile another, conditional attributes interest attributes. ‚úÖ Better matches real-world behavior ‚úÖ Explicitly captures comparative decision-making ‚úÖ Reveals true tradeoffs feature prioritization

title: Choice-Level Analysis
text: üîé conjoint design presents two profiles comparison, choice-level analysis essential valid insightful inference. üìà provides deeper insights, accurate estimates, closer reflection actual decision-making.

text: .data projoint_data object created reshape_projoint() make_projoint_data(). .qoi Optional. projoint_qoi object targeting custom quantities interest. .by_var Character. Optional. dichotomous variable subgroup analysis (e.g., Republican vs Democrat). available **profile-level** analysis. Ignored choice-level analysis. .structure Character. Either "profile_level" (default) "choice_level". .qoi supplied, structure specified overrides . .estimand Character. Either "mm" (marginal mean) "amce" (average marginal component effect). .qoi supplied, estimand specified overrides . .se_method Character. Standard error method: "analytical" (default), "simulation", "bootstrap". .irr Numeric NULL (default). NULL, IRR estimated repeated tasks; otherwise, user-supplied IRR. .remove_ties Logical. ties choice data removed estimation? Defaults TRUE. .ignore_position Logical. choice-level analysis. position profiles (left/right) ignored? Default TRUE. .n_sims Integer. Required .se_method = "simulation". Number simulation draws. .n_boot Integer. Required .se_method = "bootstrap". Number bootstrap samples. .weights_1, .clusters_1, .se_type_1 Arguments passed lm_robust estimating IRR. .clusters_1 Cluster ID variable IRR estimation. Passed lm_robust(). Default NULL. .se_type_1 Standard error type IRR estimation. Passed lm_robust(). Default "classical". .weights_2, .clusters_2, .se_type_2 Arguments passed lm_robust estimating MMs AMCEs. .clusters_2 Cluster ID variable MM/AMCE estimation. Passed lm_robust(). Default NULL. .se_type_2 Standard error type MM/AMCE estimation. Passed lm_robust(). Default "classical".

code: reshape_projoint(   .dataframe,   .outcomes,   .choice_labels = c("A", "B"),   .alphabet = "K",   .idvar = "ResponseId",   .repeated = TRUE,   .flipped = TRUE,   .covariates = NULL,   .fill = FALSE )

title: Reshapes survey response data for conjoint analysis ‚Äî reshape_projoint
text: .dataframe data frame, preferably read_Qualtrics .outcomes character vector identifying column names contain outcomes. repeated task, LAST element vector. .choice_labels c("", "B") (default): vector identifying possibilities outcome variables ‚Äì e.g., c("Candidate ", "Candidate B") .alphabet "K" (default): letter indicating conjoint attributes. using Strezhnev's package (https://github.com/astrezhnev/conjointsdt) Qualtrics. .idvar "ResponseId" (default): character identifying column name containing respondent .repeated TRUE (default) repeated task (recommended). repeated task first task. .flipped TRUE (default) profiles repeated task flipped (recommended) .covariates NULL (default): character vector identifying respondents' covariates used subgroup analysis .fill FALSE (default): logical vector: TRUE want use information whether respondent chose profile repeated task "fill" (using `tidyr` package) missing values non-repeated tasks, FALSE (otherwise). number respondents small, number specific profile pairs interest small, /number specific respondent subgroups want study small, worth changing option TRUE. please note `.fill = TRUE` based assumption IRR independent information contained conjoint tables. Although empirical tests suggest validity assumption, unsure , better use default value (FALSE).
